utterances: Well, definitely, my mom will be here, so that'll be exciting.

Congratulations.
Thank you so much.
You know, we forgot to introduce this gentleman on guitar.
Yes.
This gentleman on guitar, who's also in my album and has played with me for years, is Tyrone Johnson, and he's amazing and such a good friend.
Tyrone, welcome.
You did a great job.
Plus, Tyrone played us through the break.
Thank you both for coming in.
Thank you, Tony.
Good luck to you.
It's a pleasure having you.
That was singer/songwriter Maiysha.
Her latest album is ""This Much Is True."" Her Grammy-nominated song is ""Wanna Be."" Joining us here in the studios at NPR West, a first time, I might add, and with guitarist, Tyrone Johnson.

I'm Tony Cox, and this is News & Notes.
Who could have seen this financial disaster coming?
Who?
Well, Nouriel Roubini, for one.
He is a Turkish born, Harvard trained, now American economist.
He's been a senior financial policy maker for the government.
He now teaches at New York University and manages a financial consulting firm — it's Roubini Global Economics — and he blogs in his free time.
Professor, welcome to Day to Day.
A pleasure being with you today.
What about the news of today, that the U.S.
government is going to spend up to $250 billion to buy equity positions in banks?
This is a step in the right direction.
The original legislation was passed by Congress was severely flawed because for the government to buy toxic assets was not enough.
And most of these banks are severely under-capitalized, and until they would get capital, they would not be able to lend to households and to firms.

Therefore, the key important step in the direction of resolving these very severe financial crisis effectually means a partial, temporary nationalization of part of the financial system, but there is no other alternative.
When you say these are temporary nationalizations, professor, when would this end?
It depends.
You know, the banks have had the option after three years to buy back, essentially, these preferred shares.
So, if the financial conditions are going to improve, there'll be an option of reprivatizing the public share in the banking system.
Of course, if things don't improve, then this government ownership of part of the banking system might continue over the time and actually, it might become larger.
If things don't get better in three years?
We have to see.

You know, banks might need more than the amount of capital that the government is inputting right now, so even earlier than that, there may be another round of recapitalization of those financial institutions.
This is not just a subprime problem.

It's subprime, it's near prime, it's prime, it's home-equity loans, it's commercial real estate, it's credit cards, it's auto loans, it's student loans, it's leverage loans, it's commercial loans, it's corporate bonds - all these things are going to pile up in a severe recession.
So talking about a subprime mortgage problem is an understatement.
This is a subprime financial system.
So this might be just the first round of several rounds of recapitalization by the government of the financial system.
You're a thoroughly trained economist.
If the government is buying parts of the banks, what kind of capitalist world are we living in?
Unfortunately, in the last few years, we had this kind of laissez-faire approach to financial-market regulations supervision that's led to this severe financial crisis.
And now, we're going to the other extreme of very, very severe government intervention in financial markets and economy.
But in the short run, there is no alternative.
Usually, central banks are known to be the lenders of last resort.
But at this point, the central banks have become the lenders of first and only resorts because no one is lending to the banks.
No one is lending to non-bank financial institution, and no one is lending to the corporate sector.
And therefore, for the time being, we need this government intervention.
It is the way to prevent a severe financial crisis and a severe economic recession.
This is one step that you laid out last week in a piece that you posted on your blog and at your monitor site, saying we need to avoid a complete financial worldwide collapse.
You laid out several points.
What else remains to be done?
What does the government need to do?
There are several other things that are missing, even if they're going in the right direction, and many of my recommendations now are being adopted.
The first one is that, at this point, demand is falling sharply, aggregate demand, and that's going to make this recession more severe.
Consumption is falling.

Residential investment is falling, and if the private sector for the time being is nervous, not going to spend, then the government has to spend more money to boost them and try to minimize the severity of this economic recession.
I've proposed a fiscal package of the order of $300 billion infrastructures, grants to state and local government, unemployment benefits, maybe a small tax rebate for the very poor.
They're going to try to boost demand directly and indirectly.
It sounds almost like the New Deal back in the '30s.
Is that what you're talking about, kind of a civilian conservation core and roads projects, that kind of thing?
Yeah, you know, our infrastructure in the U.S.
is totally crumbling.
We have to invest in roads, in ports, in bridges.
OK.
And we have to do that.
That's necessary.
OK.
And then the second thing?
And the second thing is that the bad loans of the banks are the heavy debt burden of the households, mortgages, credit cards, student loans, auto loans.
And a fraction of the housing sector is insolvent, and they're not going to start spending that gain until you reduce the debt burden.
During the Great Depression, we created these homeowners' loan corporation.
The government bought the mortgages, reduced the face value, converted them into fixed-rate mortgages of long-term maturity, and we've avoided tsunami foreclosures.
We need the same thing this time around.
Two years ago at a big international finance meeting, you got up and said, the train is going to jump the tracks.
And you were almost spot on on what was going to happen over the next couple of years.
After that meeting, people went around saying, well, his math is no good.
He doesn't really know what he's talking about.
Now, you're kind of vindicated, I guess, but how good could you feel about that?
You know what?
People don't understand this but I love this job.
It is stimulating and it's fun.

And one final note, much to the surprise maybe of a lot of folks around the country, Democrats and Republicans and members of the press, and a lot of folks in this town have been an extraordinary source of help and comfort for me.
And it's one of the dirty little secrets about Washington.
It's a small town, but there're an awful lot of good people in it.
Okay, let's not get the word around too fast.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Tony Snow, thank you very much for talking with us.
Robert, thank you.
That's White House press secretary Tony Snow.
NPR's senior news analyst Daniel Schorr was struck by one winner in particular at last night's Oscars.
But the awards show didn't get politics off his mind for long.
Actually, there are two contests in progress.

Among Republicans, the issue of troops in Iraq is muted by the pressure to stand behind their president in his dark hour when best friend Tony Blair has unexpectedly announced the withdrawal of 1,600 British troops from Iraq.
While the president's approval rating in a USA Today poll has sunk to 37 percent, among Republicans, 72 percent believe that he did not make a mistake in sending troops to Iraq.
